thoughtLeadershipPost.content:
After 10 years in tech, I've learned that the best products aren't built by following trends, but by deeply understanding user problems. Here are 5 lessons that changed how I build:

1. Talk to users daily
2. Ship fast, iterate faster
3. Focus beats features
4. Culture compounds
5. Solve real pain, not imagined ones

What lessons have shaped your product philosophy?

opinionPost.content: Unpopular opinion: Most companies don't need microservices. I've seen too many teams complicate their architecture for problems they don't have. Start with a monolith. Split when you actually feel the pain. Your 5-person startup doesn't need the same architecture as Netflix. Focus on solving customer problems, not engineering flex.

questionPost.content:
Quick poll for PMs: What's your biggest challenge right now?

A) Getting engineering resources
B) Prioritization / saying no
C) Understanding user needs
D) Stakeholder alignment

Comment with your letter + one sentence on why. Trying to understand common pain points across the PM community.
